awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Coordinated Experiments and Simulations of Near-Surface Turbulent Flow over Barchan Dunes: Informing Models of Dune Migration and Interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Christensen, Kenneth / Best, James / Anderson, William
Proposal Number: 1603211 / 1604155 / 1603254

The focus of the proposed research is to explore the migration of sand dunes in large scale, desert environments or ocean floor environments. The proposed collaborative approach involves experiments, theory and simulations to understand the process of dune migration under turbulent flow. The findings of this work can be important for Aeolian dune migration, a problem that can be critical to predicting and mitigating desertification as it occurs in the Western US and in other places in the world.

Understanding and predicting the morphodynamics of subaqueous barchan dunes is critical for management of waterways and quantifying transport of nutrients and pollutants. Similarly, understanding these processes for aeolian barchan dunes is important for characterizing desertification processes and for informing numerical weather prediction. At large dune spacings, barchan kinematics can be accurately predicted using sediment transport models predicated on mean bed shear stress. However, barchans typically occur in fields. Since dune migration rate is size dependent, a heterogeneous dune field will result in variable bedform spacing, with smaller (faster) dunes approaching larger (slower) dunes. Thus, when two dunes are in close proximity, the upstream one will produce an unsteady, turbulent wake that will sculpt the morphology of the downstream one, introducing significant morphological complexity owing to spatially-heterogeneous turbulence. Such effects are not captured by current state-of-the-art models. (These approaches simulate the bedform evolution but do not resolve the overlying flow; they instead use a spatially homogeneous representation of turbulence as the flow input). Informed by preliminary research, and compelled by deficiencies in existing dune modeling approaches, it is hypothesized that the "missing link" to elucidating the morphodynamics of interacting barchan dunes is the unsteady nature of the turbulence generated within the inter-dune space. It is proposed to pursue a collaborative research effort that leverages an innovative measurement protocol and scientific computing, complemented by observations in nature. The results will transform the understanding of dune-dune flow field interactions for fixed-bed dunes as a function of proximity and volumetric ratio and will form the basis for advancing morphodynamic models. Planar and volumetric PIV measurements will be conducted in a refractive-index-matched environment (allowing unprecedented optical access to the flow) for targeted dune configurations. These experiments will validate large-eddy simulations that will enable larger spatial volumes and a much broader suite of dune field parameters to be explored, with the latter informed by field observations. The culminating task will involve incorporating the turbulence heterogeneity identified into existing morphodynamic models to test the hypothesis.  The proposed work will have an impact not only in fluid dynamics through its impact on engineering turbulent flows, but also to other disciplines including boundary-layer meteorology, geomorphology and sedimentology.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The flow-sediment interaction processes responsible for complex dune geometries remains the topic of ongoing research, ultimately due to the disparate timescales exhibited by both systems. In addition to the inherent complexity encompassed by aerodynamic response to “developed” dunes, wherein a balance exists between sediment supply and migration, dune development is an important open question. In this scenario, so-called “proto” dunes – bedforms responding rapidly to sediment availability – develop towards established dunes. These protodunes lack the crescentic  forms exhibited by established barchans, with their morphology changing rapidly from isolated sediment mounds with increasing height over wavelength, or slope. Such forms are found in locations with adequate aerodynamic loading and sediment availability; one such example of this occurs at the White Sands National Monument (WSNM) in southern New Mexico, where a desiccated lake – Lake Lucero – provides year-round sediment, while the dominant spring winds mobilize sediment and sustain formation of incipient protodunes. Throughout the research effort, the PI and supporting doctoral student, Santosh Rana, have used an existing digital elevation model (DEM) from WSNM to recover realistic protodunes. In addition, these actual protodunes dunes are used to recover salient attributes and build reduced-order protodunes. This work is also being incorporated with theoretical efforts to capture the aerodynamic signature of emergent protodunes: that is, skin friction versus Reynolds number for forms with varying slope in the laminar and transitional regime. These topics will encompass the final year of the project.

 

Anderson and supporting doctoral students – Chao Wang and  Santosh Rana – focused on addressing the transitional process from isolated sediment mounds to established barchan morphology. This transitional process is replete with challenges, as nonlinear flow physics respond to changing dune morphology and alter the spatial patterns of erosion, deposition, and thus migration. The research effort was composed of two major activities: (1) theoretical; and (2) via computer simulation with large-eddy simulation (LES). Item (1) is composed of developing a laminar and transitional flow solver for laminar flow over a spanwise-homogeneous, streamwise-harmonic topography. The topography amplitude and wavelength is systematically varied to alter the slope, which affects the flow response. In addition to the slope, we will alter the inertial conditions – for example, Reynolds number based on freestream velocity and topography amplitude – in order to capture the aerodynamic signature of varying synthetic protodune attributes as they undergo development to established barchans. These insights are being reconciled with existing theoretical treatments on protodune development, which trace back to pioneering work by Hanratty and company, Jackson, Hunt and company, and Claudin and company; these studies persistently report anomalous behavior in the laminar to turbulent regime (the so-called “Hanratty anomaly”). We hypothesize that this a consequence of intermittent, transitional-regime flow processes, and our efforts will definitively address this longstanding issue. These insights will enable generalization of existing models. The LES efforts will provide detailed space-time flow physics during instantaneous realizations of actual protodunes from the White Sands National Monument. These results will provide insights on flow-sediment morphodynamic coupling responsible for development of protodunes. 

 

Anderson and supporting doctoral students successfully recovered the protodune DEMs and have entered these as lower boundary conditions in LES. The simulations are ongoing and post processing of results will commence soon – these results will be further processed and disseminated in the APS DFD meetings in 2016-2019 and 2021, and in a series of articles summarized herein. In addition, we have coded up the laminar/transitional flow solver; this solver will be used in coming months to recover skin friction-Reynolds number trends, which can be contrasted against results from existing models to explain Hanratty’s anomolgy. 

 

Results from the research effort were disseminated via a series of conference presentations and peer-review articles. Anderson also presented the results in a series of invited seminars. These items are noted below.

 

Peer-Review Articles:

(*Grant-supported student of Anderson; +Corresponding author):

Wang C*, Tang Z, Bristow N*, Blois G, Christensen KT, Anderson W+, 2016: Computers and Fluids, DOI: 10.1016/j.compfluid.2016.11.005.

Wang C*, Anderson W+, 2018: Physical Review E 98, 033112-1—15.

Wang C*, Anderson W+, 2019: Turbulence Coherence Within Canonical and Realistic Aeolian Dune-Field Roughness Sublayers, Boundary-Layer Meteorology 173, 409–434.

Rana S*, Day M, Anderson W, Geophysical Research Letters 47, e2020GL088050-1–9.

Rana S*, Anderson W, J. Geophysical Research-Atmos. 126, e2020JD033493-1–21.

 

This project has major implications for the dune morphodynamics community, wherein input arguments from the flow field are used to drive morphodynamic models. By generalizing the flow description (based on our own research), morphodynamic models will be materially improved such that actual protodune evolution can be captured.


Last Modified: 02/07/2023
Modified by: William Anderson
